answers.author: Dave McClees
answers.text:
I did seven (7) years work on a large neighborhood vitality study across four (4) neighborhoods with their comparison neighborhoods for a six (6) year time series, in part to develop a million point data set for a dissertation and presented at several conferences.  There are a number of factors to consider, including creatingt some indicies.  First, every neighborhood and region is different had has factors that differ in terms of their relative importance pursuant to vitality (health) of the neighborhood.  The variables that you use and weighting the of them in creation of an index "algorithium" need to be taylored somewhat to the particular neighoorhood context.   As with all economics, there is not a standardized index that can be universally applied to more than one neighborhood or type of neighboehood.  Given those caviats, I will be happy to discuss defining and measuring neighborhood vitality with you, if you wish.  (757) 385-8448

Creative Vitality Index - http://www.seattle.gov/arts/news/reports_research.asp 
A strong arts and culture sector and a creative workforce help fuel our economy. The Creative Vitality Index is an annual measure of the health of the creative economy in cities, counties and states. 2007 data ranked Seattle's overall creative vitality at 5.68 times the national average, up from 5.30 in 2005. Seattle's percentage of creative occupations—including writers, architects, actors and animators—is seven times the national average. Revenues for nonprofit arts organizations are more than eight times the national average. In the four years of tracking data for the index, the 2007 figures represented a high point.  In partnership with the Washington State Arts Commission and Western States Arts Federation, the Office of Arts & Cultural Affairs created the Creative Vitality Index (CVI) to measure the city's creative edge and chart annual participation in the arts along with arts-related activities and employment.
